questions.text: Botryomycosis is a:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bacterial infection. Botryomycosis is a chronic bacterial infection that resembles a fungal infection due to its appearance but is actually caused by bacteria, most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This condition typically presents with nodular, abscess-like lesions and is often associated with trauma or compromised immune systems. The name "botryomycosis" is misleading, as it refers to the grape-like appearance of the lesions rather than any fungal involvement. A. Superficial fungal infection is incorrect. Botryomycosis is not caused by a fungus. Although the condition may have a similar appearance to fungal infections, it is bacterially induced and does not involve any fungal pathogens. C. Deep fungal infection is incorrect. Botryomycosis is not a deep fungal infection. It is a bacterial infection that affects the skin and soft tissues, and it does not involve deep tissue or systemic fungal pathogens. D. Viral infection is incorrect. Botryomycosis is caused by bacteria, not a virus. Viral infections typically have different clinical presentations, such as rashes or systemic symptoms, and do not form the characteristic nodular abscesses seen in botryomycosis.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for Actinomycotic mycetoma is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Welsh regimen. The Welsh regimen is the treatment of choice for actinomycotic mycetoma, which is a type of mycetoma caused by actinomycetes, a group of bacteria. This regimen typically includes a combination of sulfonamides and rifampicin, which effectively target the actinomycetes responsible for the infection. The Welsh regimen has proven to be highly effective in treating actinomycotic mycetoma, reducing the need for surgical intervention and improving patient outcomes. A. Sulfonamides is incorrect. While sulfonamides are part of the Welsh regimen, they alone are not sufficient as the primary treatment for actinomycotic mycetoma. Sulfonamides work best when combined with other antibiotics like rifampicin in the Welsh regimen. C. Erythromycin is incorrect. Erythromycin is an antibiotic primarily used for treating infections caused by Gram-positive bacteria, including some respiratory and skin infections. However, it is not the first-line treatment for actinomycotic mycetoma, where combination therapy like the Welsh regimen is more effective. D. Tetracycline is incorrect. Tetracycline is an antibiotic that can treat a wide variety of bacterial infections, but it is not the preferred treatment for actinomycotic mycetoma. The Welsh regimen, which includes sulfonamides and rifampicin, remains the most effective choice.

questions.text: Most common type of cutaneous T.B. is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis (TB). It typically presents as chronic, painless, reddish-brown lesions on the skin, often on the face and neck. These lesions may have a characteristic "apple jelly" appearance when examined under diascopy, which is due to the accumulation of granulomatous tissue. Lupus vulgaris results from the hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and it is the most prevalent type of cutaneous TB worldwide. B. Scrofuloderma is incorrect. Scrofuloderma occurs when TB spreads from underlying infected lymph nodes or bones to the skin. It usually presents as ulcerative lesions, often around the neck or other lymphatic regions. While it is a common form of cutaneous TB, lupus vulgaris is more frequently encountered. C. T.B. verrucosa cutis is incorrect. T.B. verrucosa cutis is a form of cutaneous TB that typically occurs after direct inoculation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis into the skin, usually due to trauma. It presents as warty or verrucous lesions, commonly on the hands or feet. It is less common compared to lupus vulgaris. D. Erythema induratum is incorrect. Erythema induratum, also known as nodular vasculitis, is a form of TB that primarily involves deep-seated nodules on the lower legs, and it is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. While it is a type of cutaneous TB, it is not as common as lupus vulgaris.

questions.text: Tuberculosis of skin is called as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis, caused by the Mycobacterium tuberculosis bacteria. It typically presents as chronic, reddish-brown lesions on the skin, particularly on the face, neck, and ears. These lesions can develop into plaques or nodules and may have an "apple jelly" appearance when pressed. Lupus vulgaris is the term specifically used to refer to tuberculosis affecting the skin. B. Lupus pernio is incorrect. Lupus pernio is a form of skin involvement seen in sarcoidosis, not tuberculosis. It presents as purple or reddish, raised, and often ulcerated lesions, primarily affecting the nose, cheeks, ears, and fingers. It is not related to tuberculosis. C. Lupus profundus is incorrect. Lupus profundus, also known as panniculitis, refers to a deeper form of lupus erythematosus (an autoimmune disease), not tuberculosis. It affects the deeper layers of the skin and subcutaneous tissue, causing firm, painful nodules. D. Lupus erythematosus is incorrect. Lupus erythematosus is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple organ systems, including the skin. It is not caused by tuberculosis and does not refer to tuberculosis of the skin. Lupus erythematosus has distinct clinical features, such as the butterfly-shaped rash across the cheeks and nose, which is not seen in tuberculosis.

questions.text: Forms of skin tuberculosis include all except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Erythema annulare centrifugum. Erythema annulare centrifugum is not a form of skin tuberculosis. It is a nonspecific inflammatory skin condition that presents as annular (ring-shaped) red patches with raised borders. It can be associated with various conditions, such as infections, medications, or systemic diseases, but it is not related to tuberculosis. A. Lupus vulgaris is incorrect. Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis. It is a chronic skin condition caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, typically characterized by reddish-brown, granulomatous lesions on the skin, often with an "apple jelly" appearance on diascopy. B. Scrofuloderma is incorrect. Scrofuloderma is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs when the infection spreads from an underlying focus of tuberculosis, such as infected lymph nodes or bones, to the skin. It results in ulcerative skin lesions, commonly around the neck or other lymphatic areas. C. Erythema induratum is incorrect. Erythema induratum (also known as nodular vasculitis) is another form of cutaneous tuberculosis. It presents as deep, painful, red-blue nodules, typically on the lower legs, and is considered a hypersensitivity reaction to Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.text: Apply-jelly nodules are seen in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lupus vulgaris. The "apple jelly" nodules are a characteristic finding in lupus vulgaris, which is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis. These nodules appear as reddish-brown, firm lesions that, when pressed, show a unique color change, resembling the color of apple jelly. This feature is a key diagnostic sign of lupus vulgaris and is caused by the accumulation of granulomatous tissue due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection. B. DLE (Discoid lupus erythematosus) is incorrect. Discoid lupus erythematosus is a chronic autoimmune condition that primarily affects the skin, causing round, scaly, erythematous lesions, especially on the face and scalp. It does not produce "apple jelly" nodules, which are specific to lupus vulgaris. C. Lichen planus is incorrect. Lichen planus is an inflammatory skin condition that presents with purple, itchy, flat-topped papules. It does not produce "apple jelly" nodules. The lesions in lichen planus are typically angular and flat, not rounded and nodular as seen in lupus vulgaris. D. Psoriasis is incorrect. Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin disorder characterized by raised, red, scaly plaques, typically on the scalp, elbows, and knees. It does not involve "apple jelly" nodules, which are a feature unique to lupus vulgaris in the context of cutaneous tuberculosis..

questions.text: Which of the following tuberculids is micropapular.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lichen scrofulosorum. Lichen scrofulosorum is a type of tuberculid that presents with small, multiple, grouped, micropapular lesions, typically on the upper trunk. These lesions are the result of a hypersensitivity reaction to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, often associated with underlying tuberculosis, such as scrofula (tuberculosis of the lymph nodes). The characteristic micropapular rash is an important diagnostic feature of this condition. B. Miliary tuberculosis is incorrect. Miliary tuberculosis refers to a widespread form of tuberculosis that affects multiple organs, particularly the lungs, and results in millet seed-like granulomas. While it can involve the skin, it does not present with micropapular lesions. The skin manifestations in miliary tuberculosis are typically more generalized, with papulovesicular or nodular lesions. C. Papulonecrotic type is incorrect. Papulonecrotic tuberculid is a cutaneous manifestation of tuberculosis that presents with necrotic papules, often with central ulceration or scarring. These lesions are not micropapular but rather have a more distinct necrotic center. D. Lupus vulgaris is incorrect. Lupus vulgaris is a chronic form of cutaneous tuberculosis that presents with reddish-brown, granulomatous plaques or nodules, often with an "apple jelly" appearance on diascopy. It is not associated with micropapular lesions, which are seen in lichen scrofulosorum.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had a gradually progressive plaque on a buttock for the last 3 years. The plaque has scarring in the center. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lupus vulgaris. Lupus vulgaris is the most common form of cutaneous tuberculosis, which can present as a slowly progressive plaque with a central scar, as described in the case. It typically develops over years, with lesions that are initially reddish-brown and may become atrophic or scarred in the center over time. The chronic, progressive nature of the plaque, with central scarring, is a characteristic feature of lupus vulgaris, and it is often seen in patients with a history of exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. A. Tinea corporis is incorrect. Tinea corporis, also known as ringworm, is a superficial fungal infection that typically presents as a red, ring-shaped rash with raised edges and a clear center. Unlike lupus vulgaris, tinea corporis does not cause chronic scarring or gradual plaque formation over such a long period, and it is usually associated with itching, not the slow progression described in this case. B. Granuloma annulare is incorrect. Granuloma annulare presents as smooth, annular plaques with a raised, edge and a normal-appearing center. These lesions often appear on the hands or feet and are generally not associated with scarring in the center or slow, progressive development over several years as seen in lupus vulgaris. D. Borderline leprosy is incorrect. Borderline leprosy, part of the leprosy spectrum, presents with various skin lesions, including hypopigmented patches or plaques with nerve involvement, but the described gradual progression and central scarring are more consistent with lupus vulgaris. Leprosy usually causes sensory loss and may involve peripheral nerves, which is not mentioned in this case.

questions.text: A young boy presented with lesion over his right buttock which had peripheral extension and central scarring. The investigation of choice would be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Biopsy. In the case of a lesion with peripheral extension and central scarring, biopsy is the investigation of choice. A biopsy allows for a definitive diagnosis by examining the tissue under a microscope. It is particularly important for conditions like lupus vulgaris or other granulomatous skin diseases, where histopathological examination is required to identify the characteristic features, such as granulomas, that differentiate them from other skin conditions. A. Tzanck smear is incorrect. A Tzanck smear is a diagnostic tool used to detect viral infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus, by identifying multinucleated giant cells in a smear of lesion fluid. However, this is not relevant for a lesion with peripheral extension and central scarring, which suggests a granulomatous or chronic infection, not a viral one. B. KOH preparation is incorrect. KOH preparation is primarily used to diagnose fungal infections, such as dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea corporis), by dissolving skin cells and allowing fungal elements to be visualized under the microscope. This is not appropriate for a lesion that exhibits scarring and peripheral extension, which points more to a granulomatous or bacterial etiology like lupus vulgaris. D. Sabouraud dextrose agar is incorrect. Sabouraud dextrose agar is a culture medium used to grow fungi, particularly dermatophytes, to diagnose fungal infections. Since the lesion described is not likely to be fungal based on the appearance (peripheral extension and central scarring), this culture method is not the appropriate diagnostic approach.

choices.text: Post primary tuberculosis with good resistance
Post primary tuberculosis with poor resistance

questions.text: Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is a form of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Post primary tuberculosis with good resistance. Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis (TBCVC) is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that occurs as a result of direct inoculation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis into the skin, typically in individuals who have already been exposed to the bacteria and have some degree of immunity. This condition is classified as post-primary tuberculosis because it develops after initial exposure and infection, and it typically occurs in individuals with good immune resistance. The lesions are usually warty or verrucous in appearance and are most commonly seen on the hands and feet, particularly in individuals who are at higher risk due to occupational exposure or trauma. A. Tuberculid is incorrect. Tuberculids are a group of hypersensitivity reactions to Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and they are not caused by direct infection with the bacteria. Conditions like lichen scrofulosorum or erythema induratum are examples of tuberculids. TBCVC, however, is a result of direct inoculation, not a hypersensitivity reaction. B. Primary tuberculosis is incorrect. Primary tuberculosis refers to the initial infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis in individuals who have not been previously exposed to the bacteria. Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is not a primary infection but rather a localized form of post-primary tuberculosis. D. Post primary tuberculosis with poor resistance is incorrect. While TBCVC is a form of post-primary tuberculosis, it occurs in individuals with good resistance to the infection, rather than those with poor resistance. In individuals with poor resistance, more aggressive forms of tuberculosis, such as miliary tuberculosis or extensive pulmonary involvement, are more likely to develop, rather than localized skin lesions like TBCVC.

questions.text: An anatomist has a single warty lesion on his hand. Which of the following could be most likely lesion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis. In this case, the anatomist’s occupation suggests a higher likelihood of direct inoculation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis into the skin, which can lead to tuberculosis verrucosa cutis (TBCVC). TBCVC typically presents as a single warty or verrucous lesion, commonly on the hands, especially in individuals who have had prior exposure to tuberculosis or have good resistance to the bacteria. This condition occurs after inoculation of the bacteria, often through trauma, and is a localized form of post-primary tuberculosis. A. Verruca vulgaris is incorrect. Verruca vulgaris, or common warts, are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and usually appear as rough, raised lesions on the skin, commonly on the hands or feet. While they are warty in appearance, they are viral in origin, not bacterial, and are less likely in this context, where tuberculosis verrucosa cutis is more relevant given the occupation and lesion characteristics. C. Mycetoma is incorrect. Mycetoma is a chronic, progressive infection typically caused by fungi or bacteria, characterized by swelling, draining sinuses, and granules in the discharge. It commonly affects the feet or hands, but the lesion described in this scenario is a single warty lesion rather than the more complex, draining nodules seen in mycetoma. D. Lichen planus hypertrophicus is incorrect. Lichen planus hypertrophicus presents as thick, scaly, purple plaques with a rough surface, often on the lower legs or other areas of the body. It does not typically present as a single warty lesion on the hand, and the condition is associated with immune-mediated inflammation, not a bacterial infection like tuberculosis.

questions.text: Skin hazards of swimming is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) M. marinum infection. M. marinum is a type of Mycobacterium that causes skin infections, particularly in individuals who are exposed to contaminated water, such as swimmers or aquarium workers. It typically leads to chronic, granulomatous skin lesions that can appear as nodules or ulcers. This infection is often referred to as "fish tank granuloma" and is linked to exposure to freshwater or saltwater environments, making it a common skin hazard for swimmers. A. Verrucae is incorrect. Verrucae, or warts, are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and are not specifically linked to swimming. While they can be contracted in communal areas like swimming pools, they are not a direct result of swimming itself or water exposure. B. Pyoderma gangrenosum is incorrect. Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare, inflammatory skin condition characterized by painful ulcers with a necrotic center. It is usually associated with systemic conditions like inflammatory bowel disease or rheumatoid arthritis. It is not specifically linked to swimming or water exposure. D. M. ulcerans infection is incorrect. M. ulcerans causes Buruli ulcer, which is typically seen in tropical and subtropical regions. While it can result from water exposure, particularly in areas where the bacteria is endemic, it is not a common hazard for swimmers in general and is less associated with recreational swimming compared to M. marinum.

questions.text: Which of the following are bacterial infections of skin
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Botryomycosis. Botryomycosis is a chronic bacterial infection of the skin caused by various bacteria, most commonly Staphylococcus aureus or Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It typically presents with nodular, abscess-like lesions that can have a characteristic grape-like appearance. This condition is a bacterial infection that mimics a fungal infection due to its appearance but is, in fact, bacterial in nature. A. Pyoderma gangrenosum is incorrect. Pyoderma gangrenosum is not caused by a bacterial infection; rather, it is an inflammatory skin condition often linked to systemic diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease or rheumatoid arthritis. It is characterized by painful, necrotic ulcers and is not an infectious process. B. Piedra is incorrect. Piedra is a superficial fungal infection caused by Trichosporon species (white piedra) or Piedraia hortae (black piedra). It affects the hair shafts, not the skin, and is not caused by bacteria. D. Impetigo herpetiformis is incorrect. Impetigo herpetiformis is a rare form of pustular psoriasis, not a bacterial infection. It is associated with pregnancy and is characterized by the appearance of pustules and erythema, particularly in areas such as the groin and axillae, but it is not caused by a bacterial pathogen.

questions.text: The causative organism of erythrasma is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Corynebacterium. Erythrasma is a superficial bacterial infection of the skin caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. This organism typically affects areas with skin folds, such as the axillae, groin, and between the toes. The infection produces reddish-brown, scaly patches, and is often diagnosed using Wood's lamp, where the affected areas fluoresce a characteristic coral-red color due to the bacteria's production of porphyrins. B. Staphylococcus is incorrect. Staphylococcus species, such as Staphylococcus aureus, are responsible for other skin infections like boils, impetigo, and cellulitis, but they do not cause erythrasma. The causative organism of erythrasma is Corynebacterium minutissimum. C. Streptococcus is incorrect. Streptococcus species, such as Streptococcus pyogenes, cause infections like erysipelas and impetigo, but not erythrasma. The latter is specifically caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum. D. Pseudomonas is incorrect. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is responsible for infections such as hot tub folliculitis, wound infections, and certain cases of cellulitis. However, it is not the causative agent of erythrasma, which is due to Corynebacterium minutissimum.

questions.text: Pemphigus neonatorum is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bullous impetigo. Pemphigus neonatorum is a form of bullous impetigo that occurs in neonates, typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus. It presents as vesicles and bullae (blisters) on the skin, often around the face, neck, and diaper area. Despite the name, it is not a form of pemphigus but rather a bacterial infection that mimics pemphigus. It is highly contagious and usually occurs in infants in hospital settings, particularly in areas where hygiene is suboptimal. B. Epidermolysis Bullosa is incorrect. Epidermolysis bullosa is a group of inherited blistering disorders where the skin is extremely fragile and blisters form with minimal trauma. The condition is genetic and congenital but does not resemble pemphigus neonatorum, which is an infectious condition rather than a genetic one. C. Congenital syphilis is incorrect. Congenital syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum and can present with a variety of skin manifestations, including bullae. However, the presentation of congenital syphilis is distinct from pemphigus neonatorum, which is caused by a bacterial infection and is characterized by superficial blisters rather than the systemic involvement and lesions of congenital syphilis. D. Pemphigus is incorrect. Pemphigus is an autoimmune blistering disorder, not a bacterial infection. It typically presents with mucosal and skin blisters, with loss of adhesion between epidermal cells. Pemphigus neonatorum, however, is not an autoimmune condition but rather a bacterial infection that appears similar to pemphigus.

questions.text: Cutaneous Tuberculosis arising from all exogenous sources, EXCEPT :
questions.solution: Correct Answer D. Lichen scrofulosorum Lichen scrofulosorum is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis known as a tuberculid. Tuberculids are distinct because they represent hypersensitivity reactions to circulating mycobacterial antigens originating from a distant, often hidden, focus of tuberculosis elsewhere in the body (e.g., lungs, lymph nodes). Therefore, their origin is always endogenous; they are not caused by direct inoculation of the bacteria into the skin from an external source. This makes Lichen scrofulosorum the most definitively "not exogenous" form among the choices. Why B is correct, but less accurate than D: Lupus vulgaris Lupus vulgaris is also primarily and overwhelmingly an endogenous form of cutaneous tuberculosis. It typically arises from the hematogenous or lymphatic spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis from an existing internal focus of infection to the skin. So, in the context of the question asking for an exception to exogenous sources, Lupus vulgaris is a correct answer as it is an endogenous form. However, some very rare and atypical cases or older theoretical discussions have described its development from direct exogenous inoculation in individuals with specific immunological states. While this is not its typical or defining pathogenesis, the existence of such rare exceptions makes it slightly less exclusively endogenous than Lichen scrofulosorum, which is never directly inoculated. Therefore, while B is factually an endogenous form, D is the most absolute and precise answer for a form that does not arise from an exogenous source. Incorrect Option: A. Warty TB (Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis) Warty TB is a classic example of exogenous cutaneous tuberculosis. It develops when Mycobacterium tuberculosis is directly inoculated into the skin through a wound, scratch, or abrasion in an individual who has developed moderate to high immunity to tuberculosis. This form is often seen in individuals with occupational exposure, such as butchers, pathologists, or medical professionals. Incorrect Option: C. Tuberculous chancre (Primary Inoculation Tuberculosis) Tuberculous chancre is another classic example of exogenous cutaneous tuberculosis. It represents the primary lesion that forms at the site of direct inoculation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis into the skin or mucous membrane of an individual who has no prior immunity to the bacteria. It is typically followed by the development of regional lymphadenopathy, forming a primary complex.

questions.text: A pathologist developed a deep seated dull red verrucous nodule which enlarged gradually on index finger. His diagnosis is likely to be :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tuberculosis Verrucosa Cutis. Tuberculosis verrucosa cutis (TBCVC) is the most likely diagnosis for a deep-seated, dull red, verrucous nodule on the index finger, particularly in a pathologist who may have had exposure to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. TBCVC is a localized form of cutaneous tuberculosis that typically occurs in individuals with prior exposure to tuberculosis and good immune resistance. The lesion develops gradually, often at sites of trauma or injury, and appears as a warty, verrucous nodule, making it the most likely diagnosis in this case. A. Verruca Vulgaris is incorrect. Verruca vulgaris, or common warts, are caused by human papillomavirus (HPV) and are typically less deep or thick compared to the lesion described here. They are more superficial and do not present as gradually enlarging deep-seated nodules with a dull red appearance like TBCVC. C. Hypertrophic Lichen Planus is incorrect. Hypertrophic lichen planus is an inflammatory skin disorder that causes thickened, violaceous plaques, typically affecting the lower legs or flexural areas. The lesions in lichen planus are usually flat-topped and not verrucous or deep-seated like those seen in TBCVC. D. Oriental Sore is incorrect. Oriental sore, also known as cutaneous leishmaniasis, is caused by Leishmania parasites and presents as a chronic ulcerative skin lesion with a raised border, often at the site of a sandfly bite. It is not characterized by the gradual, verrucous nodule formation seen in TBCVC and does not occur in the same setting or with the same presentation as described in this case.

choices.text: Linear deposition of IgA at the dermoepidermal junction

questions.text: A 7 yr old boy presents with appearance of multiple vesicles which enlarged to form flaccid bullae which had purulent contents. When they ruptured they left behind brown crusting. The most likely cause of the disease is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Infection by Staphylococcus aureus. The description of multiple vesicles that enlarge to form flaccid bullae, which rupture and leave behind brown crusting, is most characteristic of impetigo, a superficial skin infection often caused by Staphylococcus aureus. Impetigo typically presents with the formation of vesicles and bullae, which may contain purulent material. Upon rupture, these lesions leave behind honey-colored crusts, a hallmark feature of this bacterial infection. This is the most likely cause of the disease in the 7-year-old boy described. A. Autoantibodies against desmosomal components is incorrect. This option refers to pemphigus vulgaris, an autoimmune blistering disorder caused by autoantibodies against desmosomal proteins, leading to intraepidermal blistering. However, the vesicles in pemphigus vulgaris are typically not filled with purulent contents, and they do not crust over in the way described here. The condition also usually presents with mucosal involvement and is not typically associated with bacterial infection. B. Autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal components is incorrect. This option refers to bullous pemphigoid, another autoimmune blistering disorder, but it involves autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal components, leading to subepidermal blistering. The lesions in bullous pemphigoid are usually tense and do not exhibit the purulent contents and crusting described here. It also typically affects older individuals and does not present in this manner in children. C. Linear deposition of IgA at the dermoepidermal junction is incorrect. This option refers to dermatitis herpetiformis, a condition associated with celiac disease and characterized by intensely pruritic, grouped vesicles and papules, usually in a symmetrically distributed pattern. While the lesions can be vesicular, they are not typically flaccid bullae with purulent contents, and they do not present with the brown crusting seen in impetigo caused by Staphylococcus aureus

questions.text: Honey colored ‘crusts are characteristic of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Impetigo. Impetigo, particularly non-bullous impetigo, is characterized by the appearance of honey-colored crusts. This superficial bacterial skin infection is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes. Initially, it presents as small vesicles or pustules that rupture, leaving behind the characteristic honey-colored crusts. This feature is one of the hallmark signs of impetigo, and it is most commonly seen in children, especially around the face, mouth, and nose. A. Nummular eczema is incorrect. Nummular eczema, or discoid eczema, presents as round or oval patches of inflamed, dry, and scaly skin. It does not form the honey-colored crusts typical of impetigo. Instead, it is characterized by dry, red patches with scaling, but no purulent or crusted appearance as seen in impetigo. C. Herpes zoster is incorrect. Herpes zoster (shingles) presents as a unilateral, painful vesicular rash that follows a dermatomal distribution. The vesicles in herpes zoster may rupture and crust, but the crusts are not typically honey-colored. Instead, they are often darker or brownish in color, and the condition is not associated with the characteristic honey-colored crusts of impetigo. D. Cutaneous diphtheria is incorrect. Cutaneous diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae and typically results in ulcers or lesions that are covered by a thick grayish membrane, rather than honey-colored crusts. The crusts in cutaneous diphtheria are not as characteristic as those found in impetigo.

questions.text: A 35 yr old male presented with a very painful ulcer with violaceous margins and undermined edges for 2 months on lower leg. He also reports a bowel problem. The likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pyoderma gangrenosum. Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare, inflammatory skin condition that presents as a painful ulcer with violaceous (purplish) margins and undermined edges, which matches the description in the case. It often develops in individuals with underlying systemic diseases, especially inflammatory bowel diseases such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, which is consistent with the patient’s report of bowel problems. The ulcerative lesions of pyoderma gangrenosum can develop rapidly and have a characteristic appearance with an expanding border, and they are typically painful. This condition is often linked to autoimmune or systemic inflammatory disorders. A. Tubercular chancre is incorrect. Tubercular chancre is a rare form of cutaneous tuberculosis that typically appears as a painless, indurated ulcer with a punched-out appearance, often occurring at the site of a traumatic inoculation with Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The ulcer described here is painful, and the patient also has a history of bowel problems, which makes tubercular chancre less likely. C. Scrofuloderma is incorrect. Scrofuloderma is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis that arises from an underlying tuberculous focus in lymph nodes or bones and typically presents as painless, draining ulcers overlying a tuberculous focus, usually in the neck or other superficial areas. The violaceous margins and painful ulcer with undermined edges are not characteristic of scrofuloderma, making this diagnosis less likely in this case. D. Vasculitic ulcer is incorrect. Vasculitic ulcers are caused by inflammation of blood vessels and typically present as deep, punched-out ulcers with irregular borders and may be associated with systemic vasculitis. While they can be painful, vasculitic ulcers do not typically have the violaceous margins and undermined edges seen in pyoderma gangrenosum. The presence of underlying bowel disease further supports pyoderma gangrenosum over a vasculitic ulcer.

questions.text: A patient presented with finger with paronychia & extensive linear wheal like pattern on upper limb. Antibiotic for treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-The given case scenario of finger with paronychia & extensive linear wheal like pattern on upper limb suggests the diagnosis of cellulitis.The most common organism is staphylococcus aureus.Amoxiclav is the drug of choice in cellulitis. Option B,C,D-Norfloxacin,Amikacin and Metronidazole are not the first line for cellulitis.

questions.text: A young patient presents with fever with rash as shown. The diagnosis would be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Dengue hemorrhagic fever presents with petechial rash. Option B-Fever and rash with purpuric angulated margins is seen in Meningococcemia. Option C-Leptospirosis can also present with hemorrhages in conjunctiva. Option D-Scrub typhus presents with eschar.

questions.text: Identify the image given below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Single lesion at the site of bite undergoes crusting is s/o eschar,which is seen in Scrub Typhus. Option B-Rocky mountain spotted fever classically include the triad of fever, headache, and a petechial or maculopapular rash. Option C-Rickettsia rickettsii is the causative agent for Rocky mountain spotted fever. Option D-Rickettsia conorii causes indian tick typhus.
